ygData.subject: Re: Kelin`s Lucid Lullaby, how ot use?
ygData.msgSnippet: I use the song for this a lot.  If I m in a group that has a lot of casters and few if any tanks I ll use lullaby.  This has two effects.  First, of course, is
ygData.messageBody:
I use the song for this a lot. If I'm in a group that has a lot of casters
and few if any tanks I'll use lullaby. This has two effects. First, of
course, is that is puts most of the mobs to sleep so that they're not doing
damage to anyone. This gives my casting group a nice luxurious time in which
to cast their spells. Second, and just as important, it tends to pull the
mobs off of them and onto me. Since I'm much more of a tank than any of the
pure casting classes this is usually a good thing.

To make a comment about another message I read regarding lullaby, at level 20
and 21 I have definitely noticed that using the Lute (or my weightless
mandolin in my case) definitely does improve lullaby. It seems to nod more
mobs longer than without. Not a HUGE difference, but noticable at 21st. So
when I absolutely MUST get the crowd under control and keep them there for a
couple of minutes while my tanks take out four or five mobs on after another,
I always equip my mandolin.

Crier Sharpsong - 21st song bard on Fennin Ro


Jason A. Farqu´┐¢
CDI at http://www.pigging.com/



----- Original Message -----
From: <kim@...>
To: <eqbards@onelist.com>
Sent: Wednesday, September 15, 1999 1:08 PM
Subject: Re: [eqbards] Kelin`s Lucid Lullaby, how ot use?

[snip useful info]

> The song is also great at getting mobs off your casters. It
> does *not* clear the hate list, but it does make them hate you
> more rather quickly, which is ok since we're decent tanks.
> While they're nodding, they're not interrupting the caster's
> spells, so your friends will be able to cast more reliably.
> My cleric friend loves this song because without it in
> multiple mob situations, the unengaged mobs tend to jump on
> the her after she heals anyone. She says if that happens, she
> just stands next to me for a few pulses and the mobs start
> attacking me again.
>
> --
> John H. Kim
